title: Quintus Catius
text:
Quintus Catius was an officer ("<a href="legatus">legatus</a>") of the <a href="Roman%20Republic">Roman Republic</a> during the <a href="Second%20Punic%20War">Second Punic War</a>.
Catius was <a href="plebeian%20aedile">plebeian aedile</a> with Lucius Porcius Licinius in 210 BC. Using money collected through fines, they dedicated bronze statues at the <a href="Temple%20of%20Ceres">Temple of Ceres</a> and presented games ("<a href="ludi">ludi</a>") that the <a href="Augustan%20literature%20%28ancient%20Rome%29">Augustan</a> historian <a href="Livy">Livy</a> says were quite magnificent for their time.
In 207 BC, Catius was left in charge of the Roman camp at <a href="Canusium">Canusium</a> when his commanding officer <a href="Gaius%20Claudius%20Nero">Gaius Claudius Tiberius Nero</a> joined <a href="Roman%20consul">consular</a> colleague <a href="Marcus%20Livius%20Salinator">Marcus Livius Salinator</a> to fight against <a href="Hasdrubal%20%28Barcid%29">Hasdrubal</a>. Nero's move was virtually unprecedented; a consul was to fight only within his own "<a href="Roman%20province">provincia</a>" with the troops assigned to him by the <a href="Roman%20senate">senate</a>, but Nero thought the circumstances justified extreme measures which also gave him an element of surprise. Catius was left to face off against <a href="Hannibal">Hannibal</a>, who decided to stay put. This delegation of authority anticipated a highly controversial case two years later concerning an egregious exercise of "<a href="imperium">imperium</a>" under <a href="Scipio%20Africanus">Scipio Africanus</a> by his legate <a href="Quintus%20Pleminius">Quintus Pleminius</a>; Catius, by contrast, had benefitted from the nearby support of the experienced and respected <a href="Quintus%20Fulvius%20Flaccus%20%28consul%20237%20BC%29">Fulvius Flaccus</a>, a four-time consul.
In 205, Catius and <a href="Marcus%20Pomponius%20Matho">Marcus Pomponius Matho</a>, who would later become the <a href="praetor">praetor</a> in charge of the investigation against Pleminius, were sent as Rome's ambassadors to <a href="Delphi">Delphi</a> with gifts to dedicate at the temple. These included a 200-pound gold crown and images ("simulacra") of the spoils seized from Hasdrubal, amounting to 1,000 pounds of silver. This embassy occurred in the context of what Livy characterizes as a sudden attack of religiosity at Rome, which in addition to a consultation with the <a href="Sibylline%20books">Sibylline books</a> resulted most famously in the importation of the <a href="Cult%20%28religion%29">cult</a> of <a href="Cybele">Cybele</a> to Rome.
Catius and Matho received favorable omens when they sacrificed to <a href="Pythian%20Apollo">Pythian Apollo</a> at Delphi. The question posed by the Roman ambassadors goes unrecorded, but the oracle responded with what was probably already a safe prediction: "The <a href="SPQR">Roman people</a> will soon have a victory much greater than that from whose spoils you have brought gifts." This was taken as confirmation of Scipio's desire to operate in Africa.
The Catii were an obscure family; the only other member to attain prominence during the Republic was <a href="Gaius%20Catius%20Vestinus">Gaius Catius Vestinus</a>, a <a href="military%20tribune">military tribune</a> in 43 BC under <a href="Mark%20Antony">Marcus Antonius</a>.
